instruction: Identify some of the main components of a computer network such as hosts, routers, switches, hubs, links, and interfaces. Explain how they communicate and coordinate with each other using protocols and standards such as TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP, DNS, DHCP, and ARP. Describe how data is transmitted and received over a network using concepts such as packets, frames, headers, addresses, ports, sockets, and checksums.
output:
A computer network consists of several components that work together to allow computers to communicate and share resources. Some of the main components of a computer network are:
1. Hosts: These are the computers or devices that are connected to the network. They can be desktop computers, laptops, tablets, smartphones, or any other type of device that can connect to the internet.
2. Routers: These are devices that route traffic between different networks. They make sure that data is transmitted from one network to another in the most efficient way possible.
3. Switches: These are devices that connect multiple hosts to a network. They act as a central hub for the network, allowing data to be transmitted quickly and efficiently.
4. Hubs: These are devices that are used to connect multiple cables together. They act as a repeater, amplifying the signal and allowing it to travel further.
5. Links: These are the physical cables that connect the various components of the network. They can be Ethernet cables, fiber-optic cables, or wireless connections.
6. Interfaces: These are the ports or connections on the various devices that allow them to connect to the network. They can be USB, RJ-45, or other types of connectors.
To communicate and coordinate with each other, the components of a computer network use protocols and standards such as TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP, DNS, DHCP, and ARP. These protocols and standards define how data is transmitted and received over the network, as well as how the various components interact with each other.
TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) is the most widely used protocol in computer networks. It is responsible for data transmission and reception over the network, and it breaks down data into smaller pieces called packets. Each packet contains a header that includes

instruction:
I discovered this popular ~9-year-old SO question and decided to double-check its outcomes.

So, I have AMD Ryzen 9 5950X, clang++ 10 and Linux, I copy-pasted code from the question and here is what I got:

Sorted - 0.549702s:

~/d/so_sorting_faster$ cat main.cpp | grep "std::sort" && clang++ -O3 main.cpp && ./a.out
    std::sort(data, data + arraySize);
0.549702
sum = 314931600000
Unsorted - 0.546554s:

~/d/so_sorting_faster $ cat main.cpp | grep "std::sort" && clang++ -O3 main.cpp && ./a.out
    // std::sort(data, data + arraySize);
0.546554
sum = 314931600000
I am pretty sure that the fact that unsorted version turned out to be faster by 3ms is just noise, but it seems it is not slower anymore.

So, what has changed in the architecture of CPU (so that it is not an order of magnitude slower anymore)?
How has artificial intelligence impacted the job market and what can we expect in the future? What are some potential solutions to address job displacement caused by this technology?
output:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has been creating a lot of buzz in recent years. With the advancement of technology and the increasing availability of data, AI has become an integral part of many industries, including healthcare, finance, and entertainment. However, as AI continues to evolve, it is also having a major impact on the job market. In this article, we will explore how AI has affected the job market and what the future might hold.
Impact on the Job Market
One of the most significant ways that AI has affected the job market is through automation. AI-powered machines can now perform tasks that were previously only possible for humans. This has led to the displacement of jobs in industries such as manufacturing, customer service, and even office work. For example, AI-powered robots can now assemble cars, while chatbots can handle basic customer inquiries. As a result, many jobs that used to require human labor are now being replaced by machines.
However, AI has not only caused job displacement. It has also created new job opportunities in areas such as data analysis, machine learning, and AI development. These jobs require specialized skills that are in high demand, especially in industries such as healthcare and finance.
The Future of AI and the Job Market
As AI continues to evolve, it is likely that more jobs will be displaced. However, there are also potential solutions that could be implemented to address job displacement caused by this technology. One solution could be retraining programs that help workers acquire new skills and transition into new careers. Additionally, governments and businesses could invest in education and training initiatives to ensure that workers are equipped with the necessary skills to succeed in the changing job market.
Another solution could be implementing policies that protect workers from job displacement.

instruction: What is the name of the actress who played the role of Rachel Green in the popular TV show ‚ÄúFriends‚Äù?

instruction:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There‚Äôs much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we‚Äôre from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‚Äòus,‚Äô we‚Äôve got a lot to say.
While you don‚Äôt need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‚Äòfoundered‚Äô sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‚Äòclinker‚Äô than ‚Äòbeezer‚Äô? Or appreciating that ‚Äògrand‚Äô can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs really important,‚Äù says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
‚ÄúI think sometimes we‚Äôre not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
‚ÄúOften the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,‚Äù he continues.
‚ÄúSlang as a sort of term that‚Äôs used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
‚ÄúWe have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that‚Äôs used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they‚Äôre really quite amazing things.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a potentially massive term,‚Äù says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
‚ÄúOne of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
‚ÄúBut then you‚Äôve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he‚Äôs been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.‚Äù
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we‚Äôre all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of those things that if we go on holiday and you‚Äôre walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‚Äòyer ma‚Äô, or ‚Äòyer man‚Äô and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don‚Äôt and can‚Äôt,‚Äù says Dr Ferguson.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there‚Äôs nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
‚ÄúSometimes we might get anxious that we‚Äôre using cliches, but we‚Äôre actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.‚Äù
Think too of Line of Duty‚Äôs Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn‚Äôt come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee‚Äôs Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
‚ÄúThat really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
‚ÄúSometimes we‚Äôve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.‚Äù
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs unfortunate that it‚Äôs been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,‚Äù says Gail.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so frustrating but I think there‚Äôs definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It‚Äôs one dimension of what slang can do.‚Äù
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
‚ÄúIn many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
‚ÄúWe have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
‚ÄúWe are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‚Äòpotatoes‚Äô that we have.
‚ÄúCertain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that‚Äôs a real strength. I think there‚Äôs a variety there and there‚Äôs a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.‚Äù
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‚Äòboak‚Äô after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‚Äòthe messages‚Äô? My favourite slang word ‚Äòhoke‚Äô has an Ulster Scots origin. It‚Äôs fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
‚ÄúOften there‚Äôs not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it‚Äôs bad language, or it doesn‚Äôt have a sense of value behind it,‚Äù says Dr Ferguson.
‚ÄúBut on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
‚ÄúThere are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it‚Äôs authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you‚Äôre in the room.
‚ÄúWhenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns‚Äô To a Mouse and ‚Äòwee, sleekit, cowrin, tim‚Äôrous beastie‚Äô appears in the first line.
‚ÄúThis really electrifies him because the word ‚Äòwee‚Äô appears. It‚Äôs the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it‚Äôs also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
‚ÄúI think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we‚Äôve grown up with, we‚Äôre maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there‚Äôs something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don‚Äôt connect us.‚Äù
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we‚Äôre trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland‚Äôs case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‚Äòwee.‚Äô
‚ÄúWe all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it‚Äôs Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we‚Äôre foundered,‚Äù says Dr Ferguson.
‚ÄúOne of our great words, and I think there‚Äôs a difference between the town and city where it‚Äôs ‚Äòscunnered‚Äô or ‚Äòscundered‚Äô. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‚ÄòI am totally scunnered‚Äô or ‚ÄòI am totally scundered‚Äô about something. These are things that we should protect.‚Äù
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
‚ÄúYesterday‚Äôs slang term is today or the future‚Äôs commonly understood term for something,‚Äù she explains.
‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs how language changes and evolves, through its users. You‚Äôre getting a people‚Äôs history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
‚ÄúEvery year I‚Äôm always interested to see what makes it into the OED ‚Äî it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
‚ÄúIn 2022, ‚Äòa chara‚Äô entered the OED. So did ‚Äòfluthered‚Äô, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‚Äògaslighter‚Äô and ‚Äòvaxxed‚Äô. It‚Äôs great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we‚Äôre living through.‚Äù
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‚Äòbeauty‚Äô of slang is that it‚Äôs often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
‚ÄúIt often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,‚Äù he laughs.
‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs a there‚Äôs a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They‚Äôre used in some circles and in some groups.
‚ÄúWe all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we‚Äôve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‚Äòuni‚Äô seems one of the obvious words to use because it‚Äôs been floating through media, but it‚Äôs loaded into everyday speech.
‚ÄúLanguage is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we‚Äôre not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.‚Äù
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they‚Äôre widely available for visitors to enjoy ‚Äî on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs actually gotten more popular,‚Äù she says of the slang-adorned items.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
‚ÄúI think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.‚Äù
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we‚Äôre proud of the places we call home.
From ‚Äòup to high doh‚Äô coasters to ‚Äòa wee bag‚Äô tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
‚ÄúI knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast ‚Äî 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,‚Äù explains Linzi.
‚ÄúWith the Americans coming over and they ask, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs ‚Äúawk hiya love?‚Äù‚Äô ‚Äì which we have on our socks and mugs ‚Äì once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they‚Äôre running around America with a pair of ‚Äòawk hiya love‚Äô socks on with people asking, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs awk?‚Äô
‚ÄúIt creates engagement in the shop and it‚Äôs probably why the shop is doing so well as it‚Äôs creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
‚ÄúIt opens conversations which is brilliant.‚Äù
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‚Äòalright big lad‚Äô and customers still love ‚ÄòUlster says yeooo!‚Äô and ‚Äòats us nai‚Äô.
‚ÄúHaving tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,‚Äù continues Linzi.
‚ÄúFor the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There‚Äôs no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.‚Äù
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
‚ÄúI was always very conscious that it‚Äôs how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it‚Äôs a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it‚Äôs quite popular.
‚ÄúIt may not want to be a mug you‚Äôd have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‚Äòalright‚Äô sock in a style that‚Äôs trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you‚Äôre able to tie those two together then you‚Äôve got a good product. It‚Äôs not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.‚Äù
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,‚Äù says Gail. ‚ÄúSimple things like I‚Äôll say ‚Äòplaster‚Äô and she‚Äôll say ‚ÄòBand-aid,‚Äô I‚Äôll say ‚Äòchips‚Äô and she‚Äôll say ‚Äòfries‚Äô. He knows that he‚Äôs betwixt and between terms.
‚ÄúEven things like ‚Äòwee‚Äô and ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs the craic?‚Äô There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who‚Äôs not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‚ÄòWell, hello, what‚Äôs the craic?‚Äô Or even words like ‚Äòscundered‚Äô or ‚Äòjammy,‚Äô or ‚Äòdead on,‚Äô all these things that I say quite often.‚Äù"
output:

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs an awes that when visitors are looking into the wordsand Irish people in the sense of our local phraseology for us,‚Äù she continues.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice to be arena and we can be proudly.‚Äù
The cold is rough.‚Äù
